entry.title: Service Interfaces and ABAP Proxy generation support in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

This blog describes how to import Service Interface objects from SAP PI /PO ESR to Cloud Integration Capability of SAP Integration Suite and also the procedure to connect SAP R3 or S/4 HANA systems to Integration Suite tenant and generate ABAP-Proxies.

This feature is available in SAP Integration Suite Cloud Integration (6.69.41 ) standard and above service plans.

Pre-requisites :

1. Configuring Cloud Connector

The first step is to configure SAP Cloud Connector with on premise ES Repository. Cloud connector is an installable application that allows you to establish communication between on premise and cloud applications. To know more about SAP Cloud Connector, see https://help.sap.com/viewer/cca91383641e40ffbe03bdc78f00f681/Cloud/en-US/e6c7616abb5710148cfcf3e75d9...

2. Configure Connection to ESR

Please refer to the following documentation for details on configuration of ESR system details in Cloud Integration Settings page.

https://help.sap.com/docs/integration-suite/sap-integration-suite/configuring-connectivity-to-es-rep...

Once the ES Repository configurations are completed, you can import the Service Interface objects  from your ES Repository.

Importing Service Interface Artifact :

1. Create a new Integration Package or Open an existing Integration Package.

2. Click on Edit and switch to the Artifacts tab

3. Expand Add menu  and select Service Interface option from the list.

4. A Wizard with title Add Service Interface  and steps to be followed is displayed. 

5. Select the SAP Process Integration system in the Name dropdown and click on connect. On successful Connection, the Service Interface artifacts present in the ES Repository of the connected SAP PI/PO system are listed.

6. Select a Service Interface and proceed with Next Step. This step displays the details (Name, Namespace) of the Service Interface that is selected for import along with the dependent Resources used in the definition of Service Interface.

 

7. On Proceeding to Next step, the Summary of the import along with the dependant resources is displayed. 

8. On Click of Add, the selected Service Interface artifact gets created and listed in the Artifacts page.

Editor for Service Interface 

9.   On click of the Service Interface artifact from the Artifacts list page, the artifact gets opened and displayed as follows:

Overview tab :

References tab : 

1)Local  : Lists the External Messages/RFCs/IDOCs used in the definition of the Operation(s) of the Service Interface artifact as shown as WSDLs

2)Global : Lists the MessageTypes/Fault Message types used in the definition of the Operation(s) of the Service Interface artifact 

Definition Tab :

WSDL :

Refer to the blog for details on configuration of SM59 destination for ABAP Proxy to connect to Integration Suite tenant and generate ABAP Proxies : ABAP Proxy generation support with SAP Integration Suite

Next Steps:

In the upcoming releases, the Edit of existing Service Interface and also Creation of Service Interface artifact in Cloud Integration capability of SAP Integration Suite would be available.

entry.title: Migrating from SAP PO to SAP Integration Suite (CPI): A Practical Guide
entry.content:
Introduction

As organizations move towards cloud-based integration platforms, migrating from SAP Process Orchestration (PO) to SAP Integration Suite (CPI) becomes essential. This blog will walk you through the key steps of this migration, focusing on:

  • Connecting SAP PO to SAP Cloud Connector And adding SAP PO in SAP Integration Suite (CPI)

  • Importing Message Mappings from SAP PO

  • Importing dependent objects of the Message Mapping,  such as Imported Archives and Function Libraries

 

‚Äå‚Äå Step 1: Connecting SAP PO to Cloud Connector

Since SAP PO is an on-premise system, we use SAP Cloud Connector to securely connect SAP CPI (cloud) to the SAP PO environment. The Cloud Connector acts as a secure tunnel between cloud applications and on-premise systems without exposing them directly to the internet.

  1. Install SAP Cloud Connector  on the same network as SAP PO (for testing install on your system).

  2. Connect Cloud Connector to your SAP BTP subaccount (SAP CPI tenant).
    Establishing a Connection Between Cloud Connector and Subaccount 

  3. Login to the SAP Cloud Connector and select the subaccount and click on Cloud to On-Premises.

  4. Add the SAP PO System in Cloud Connector.

    Back-end Type: ABAP System
    Protocol: HTTP
    Internal Host: *PO Sytem Host Name without http://*
    Internal Port: *PO Sytem port*
    Virtual Host: *Enter a desired virtual hostname. This will be used when connecting from Integration suite.*
    Virtual Port: *Enter a desired port*
    Allow Principal Propagation: check‚úîÔ∏è
    Principal Type:Kerberos
    Host in Request Header: Use Virtual Host
    Next ==> Next==>
    Check Internal Host: check‚úîÔ∏è
    Finish

     

  5. Add resources path by clicking on the + icon and enter / select Path and all Sub-Paths ==> Save.

  6.  Check whether the added SAP PO system is reachable.

    If it's not, cross-check the host and port. Ensure that both the SAP PO system and the Cloud Connector are accessible through the same network.

  7.  Now we have successfully connected to SAP PO system from SAP Cloud Connector.

Step 2: Connecting SAP PO  to SAP Integration Suite(CPI) Through SAP Cloud Connector

 

  1. Login to the Integration suite, Go to settings ==> Integrations==> select System Tab==> click on +  to add the SAP PO Sytem.

  2. Enter the details of System Overview and Integration Directory.

    In the Address box, enter the Virtual Host and Port with http://, as maintained in the Cloud Connector.
    If your PO System uses the same address for both the Integration Directory and the ES Repository, check the corresponding checkbox‚úîÔ∏è. Otherwise, specify them separately. 
  3. Test the connectivity between Integration suite and SAP PO system.

  4.  Now we have successfully connected to SAP PO system from Integration suite.

Step 3: Importing Message Mappings from SAP PO to SAP CPI

  1.  Login to the Integration suite and go to your package and click on Add message mapping. Selcet ES Repository and select the added SAP PO System and connect.

  2.  Select the required message mapping and click on next.

  3.   To import Message mappings there are some prerequisites:

    Based on your message mapping, you may have dependent resources such as a Function Library, Imported Archive, WSDL, or XSD. 

    WSDL and XSD files are imported automatically along with the message mapping. However, Function Libraries and Imported Archives must be imported separately.

    After selecting the message mapping, you will be able to see the list of dependent resources. You must import the required resources (Function Library and Imported Archive) first; otherwise, the message mapping cannot be imported successfully.

     

 

  1. Importing Dependent Objects: Function Libraries
    1. Create a function library artifact, click on "Upload," connect to the SAP PO system, select your function libraries, save, and then deploy.

    2.  Create a Imported Archives artifact, click on "Upload," connect to the SAP PO system, select your Imported Archives, save, and then deploy.

           4. Since the dependent objects have been imported, we can now import the message mapping. Add the message                               mapping artifact, select the ES Repository, choose the added SAP PO system, connect, select the message mapping,                     click "Next," and then select the dependent objects that were imported as separate artifacts.

5. Click on "Select" and choose the required function library artifact.

6. If the status shows "Already Existing," click on it and select "Reuse Existing Resource.

 

7. Next, click on "Select" and choose the required imported archive artifact. Then, click "Submit" to import the message      mapping.

 8.  Now the Message Mapping is successfully imported to Integration suite from SAP PO system.

 

Conclusion

Migrating from SAP PO to SAP CPI goes beyond a simple technical shift‚Äîit‚Äôs an opportunity to modernize integration landscapes, adopt cloud-first patterns, and leverage the flexibility of SAP BTP. By carefully setting up connectivity through the Cloud Connector, systematically migrating message mappings, and addressing dependencies like archives and function libraries, you can ensure a smooth and reliable transition.

A phased migration approach, combined with thorough testing and best practices, will help minimize risk and maximize value. This journey not only preserves existing investments but also sets the stage for future-ready integrations.

Stay tuned for my upcoming blogs, where I‚Äôll deep dive into adapter migration strategies and lessons learned from real project experiences. üöÄ

entry.title: IDOCs are Still Safe for SAP S/4HANA - SAP Clean Core Extensibility Level B
entry.content:
Intro 

IDOCs are safe to use in SAP S/4HANA programs‚Äîand if anyone tells you otherwise, point them to this blog to learn more. IDOCs are now officially part of SAP Clean Core Extensibility! That‚Äôs the big news from updated SAP Guidelines (OSS Note 3578329 ‚Äì Frameworks, Technologies and Development Patterns in Context of Clean Core Extensibility).

This ends the myth that IDOCs are ‚Äúdead.‚Äù They are not. They‚Äôre preserved as SAP Clean Core Level B Extensibility, which means your existing IDOC investments are safe. Let‚Äôs explore four perspectives‚Äîintegration, monitoring and error handling, performance, and testing‚Äîto see where APIs are recommended first, and where IDOCs still bring value.

1. Integration Perspective

SAP‚Äôs recommendation for new development in S/4HANA is clear: use modern integration technologies such as APIs, events, or OData services. They are the strategic direction and best fit for greenfield or transformation projects. That said, not all projects require reinvention. If your business processes remain largely the same as in ECC, and the goal is to reduce cost and risk, IDOCs can still be used. They are not prohibited, and as long as an IDOC type is not listed as deprecated in the SAP Simplification List, it is safe:
https://help.sap.com/docs/btc/lean-sdt-best-practices/sap-s-4hana-simplification-analysis?locale=en-US Because IDOCs are now Clean Core Level B Extensibility, continuing with them is fully supported in SAP S/4HANA on-premise and SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud. They offer a pragmatic path to de-risk projects and leverage existing know-how.‚ÄÉ

2. Monitoring and Error Handling Perspective

For new interfaces, SAP recommends using AIF (Application Interface Framework) to handle monitoring, error management, and business validations. AIF provides a powerful, unified monitoring layer, and in many cases it comes license-free (for standard SAP interfaces delivered in namespaces like /SDSLS or /LEEDI, or in CFIN, Document Compliance, or S/4HANA Public Cloud). Where APIs are deployed, AIF bridges the gap between technical payloads and business-friendly monitoring.

IDOCs still have a strong card here: their monitoring capabilities are mature, well-known, and integrated into standard SAP transactions. Functional users know how to work with WE02, BD87, and standard reprocessing flows. This means less training, less overhead, and faster resolution in day-to-day operations.

In other words: AIF is recommended, but IDOCs deliver proven stability in monitoring and error handling.

3. Performance Perspective

APIs are the recommended way forward, but they come with a structural tradeoff: their payloads are larger and typically handle transactions individually. This makes them more verbose and sometimes less efficient for high-volume use cases. IDOCs, in contrast, have long supported bundling, batching, and parallel processing at scale. They‚Äôve been the backbone of high-volume EDI and SAP-to-SAP integrations for decades, and their ability to handle millions of documents daily is field-proven. So while APIs are the strategic choice for new designs, IDOCs remain a safe performance option for scenarios with heavy data throughput.

4. Testing Perspective

Testing support for APIs exists (for example, with SXI_MONITOR), but it is more technical and often requires additional training for functional teams. For IDOCs, simulation and reprocessing are familiar to almost every SAP functional consultant. Tools like WE19 and BD87 make IDOC testing and troubleshooting accessible, reducing dependency on specialist skills.

For projects that need to standardize and automate testing across both APIs and IDOCs, solutions like Int4 Suite provide simulation and test automation capabilities that unify all SAP integration scenarios. You can learn more on how to test and simulate SAP integrations in this SAP learning Course: Avoid SAP S/4HANA Project Delays with Third-Party Systems Service Virtualization So while APIs are recommended for new developments, IDOCs still offer ease of testing and proven tooling, especially in brownfield projects.

Conclusion

The strategic path forward in SAP S/4HANA is built on APIs, events, and frameworks like AIF. That‚Äôs the official recommendation, and it should guide greenfield and transformation projects. But IDOCs are far from obsolete. They are officially part of Clean Core extensibility, safe to use in both on-premise and private cloud, and carry unique advantages in performance, monitoring, and ease of testing. That makes them not only supported, but still a pragmatic and safe choice when the situation calls for stability, cost reduction, and risk mitigation.

entry.title: Int4 Suite Agents Empowers Functional Consultants To Test Integrated SAP S/4HANA Business Processes
entry.content:
Introduction 

Integrated business processes are the bloodstream of SAP systems. Every Sales Order, Purchase Order, Delivery, and Invoice has to flow smoothly, not just within SAP, but across EDI partners (customer, vendors, 3PL partners) banks, warehouses, tax portals.

Here‚Äôs the paradox: SAP S/4HANA projects have plenty of sophisticated automation tools, but they rarely help functional consultants in their manual tests. Instead, those tools get pushed into the narrow niche of automation testers. Functional consultants treat them like mythical dragons, complicated, dangerous, and likely to drag them away from their real work into procedural swamps.

The result? Slow testing cycles, dependency on integration specialists, and endless waiting for external partners to provide messages or confirmations.

Changing the story with simulation agents

The better path is not to force functional consultants into scripting or automation frameworks, but to give them simulation agents that mimic the system environment.

Instead of saying: ‚Äúlearn a test framework and run automated scripts,‚Äù we can say: ‚Äúhere are agents that simulate your missing EDI partner, your unavailable 3rd party/legacy system and you can test with them right now.‚Äù

This changes the game:

  • No competition with automation teams.
  • No learning curve with complex frameworks and procedural delays.
  • Consultants get something they instantly understand: realistic test conditions on demand, using actual historical production data.

How Int4 Suite Agents Work

With Int4 Suite, simulation agents provide a simple interface: the consultant performs the transaction in SAP, the agent feeds in authentic historical test data, and then automatically checks whether the newly generated EDI or non-EDI message matches what was sent in production.

Below are examples of key agents and how they fit into typical integrated OTC and P2P processes

Figure - meet the Int4 Suite Agents 

EDI Partner Agent (based on historical data)

Role: Replays authentic production EDI messages from trading partners (ORDERS, DESADV, INVOIC).

How it works:

  • Consultant performs the transaction in SAP (e.g., creates delivery, sends invoice).
  • Agent provides historical test data from previously exchanged documents.
  • Agent automatically compares the newly generated EDI message with the production one for a similar case.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant in the OTC team replays historical ORDERS from the largest customer and verifies whether, after pricing condition changes, the system still calculates correctly.
  • Consultant tests goods receipt with historical DESADV data; agent compares the new EDI message against the production one.
  • Consultant issues a sales invoice (INVOIC) and agent validates it against the original production invoice, checking VAT rules.

Figure - Select Historical EDI messages from Production system which need to be rerun on Test System 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant creates a purchase order; agent provides a historical ORDRSP where the supplier delivered partially, then compares the new outbound message.
  • Agent simulates a supplier INVOIC and verifies whether workflows behave the same after configuration changes.

Figure - manipulate the historical/production landscape EDI message data before sending that to the test environment

Unavailable System Agent (Non-SAP)

Role: Simulates external systems (banks, customs, WMS/TMS, tax portals) with historical production communications.

How it works:

  • Consultant runs the business process in SAP.
  • Agent injects historical test data from the external system.
  • Agent compares the new outbound message with the original production one.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant tests e-invoicing using a historically rejected invoice; agent checks whether the new output matches the original and if the new rules handle it.
  • Consultant tests shipment confirmations with historical WMS responses.

P2P examples:

  • Consultant tests bank payments; agent supplies historical payment files and checks the new output structure.
  • Consultant tests tax submissions; agent provides historical records and compares new vs. old messages.

Figure - Display the historical EDI data used on production landscape before rerunning that on the test environment 

Historical Data Agent

Role: The production message librarian, replays large volumes or special cases directly from production.

How it works:

  • Consultant triggers transactions in SAP (bulk orders, invoices, returns).
  • Agent provides the historical payloads.
  • Agent verifies test messages against the production equivalents.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant replays a ‚ÄúBlack Friday‚Äù scenario with 10,000 ORDERS; agent validates each new EDI message against its production twin.
  • Consultant tests credit memo flows from historical complaint cases.

Figure ‚Äì run many historical messages on the test environment for bulk testing purposes 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant tests bulk supplier invoices; agent validates the outputs against production.
  • Consultant tests blocked spare-parts orders with historical references.

Integration Consultant Agent

Role: A technical assistant that retrieves and compares messages from middleware layers (PI/PO, CPI).

How it works:

  • Consultant executes the business process in SAP.
  • Agent fetches the historical integration payload.
  • Agent highlights differences between new and historical messages.

OTC examples:

  • Consultant creates a sales order; agent compares the IDoc/XML message with the historical SAP Integration Suite payload.
  • Agent highlights mapping differences at field level after configuration changes.

Figure ‚Äì fetch an EDI payload produced by the integration platform (SAP Integration Suite, etc.) from a newly created business document and compare with the historical one from the production landscape without asking SAP Integration Consultant for help 

P2P examples:

  • Consultant enters a supplier invoice; agent pulls historical Ariba-CPI payload and checks consistency.
  • Agent validates purchase order messages across production and test runs.

Why it matters for SAP S/4HANA projects

In S/4HANA transformations, the external world doesn‚Äôt care about your internal redesigns. Customers, suppliers, and banks still expect exactly the same messages they used to get. Outbound and inbound interfaces are fragile bridges that must remain stable.

By equipping functional consultants with Int4 Suite agents:

  • Test cycles shorten dramatically.
  • Reliance on external partners and scarce integration resources drops.
  • Confidence in end-to-end quality rises.

This isn‚Äôt about replacing automation experts or integration teams. It‚Äôs about enabling functional consultants to independently confirm that what leaves SAP (or comes into it) is still what the outside world expects.

It‚Äôs the missing puzzle piece for smooth, low-friction testing of integrated business processes in SAP transformations.

More information: 

Agentic AI Testing for Greenfield S/4HANA Outbound Interfaces - Part 1
Int4 Suite ‚Äî your SAP Joule testbed and skills builder
Process-Aware Agentic Testing of SAP with Int4 Suite
Agentic Testing and Simulation with Int4 Suite's SAP Business Knowledge Graph

entry.title: Extensibility in the Age of AI: Why ABCD Is Easier (and Smarter) Than You Think
entry.content:
The CTO‚Äôs Concern

Not long ago, during a client conversation, a CTO expressed a concern that resonated deeply:

‚ÄúWe need to extend our system. But every time someone says ‚Äòlet‚Äôs customize this,‚Äô I feel we‚Äôre piling risk. And now with AI coming, I‚Äôm afraid our mess gets worse.‚Äù

That statement captures the heart of a challenge many SAP customers face. Customization has been both the strength and the Achilles‚Äô heel of enterprise landscapes. It allows us to adapt, innovate, and differentiate ‚Äî but it often comes with technical debt, upgrade pain, and hidden complexity.

Why Extensibility Matters More in the AI Era

Let‚Äôs pause here. Ten years ago, if you added a Z-table or tweaked a user exit, the worst-case scenario was some testing pain during an upgrade. Today?

  • If your data model is inconsistent, your AI forecasts won‚Äôt align with reality.
  • If your logic is buried in old exits, Joule copilots can‚Äôt ‚Äúsee‚Äù your processes.
  • If your core is brittle, cloud updates feel like risks, not opportunities.

In other words: extensibility is no longer just about ‚Äúmaking it work.‚Äù It‚Äôs about making AI possible.

And now, with SAP‚Äôs AI ambitions accelerating ‚Äî embedded copilots, Joule agents, and business data clouds powering predictive intelligence ‚Äî the messy customizations of the past risk becoming blockers for the future.

This is where ABCD extensibility comes in. Far from being abstract jargon, it‚Äôs a practical compass to guide enterprises on how to extend the system smartly, safely, and in a way that enables AI instead of hindering it.

The ABCD Levels: A Human Explanation

SAP‚Äôs ABCD framework doesn‚Äôt exist to confuse us ‚Äî it exists to help customers navigate the grey space between innovation and stability.

Here‚Äôs the official breakdown, with real-world translation:

A Short Story: The MV45AFZZ Debate

Anyone who has worked in SAP Sales and Distribution knows the legendary include MV45AFZZ. For decades, it‚Äôs been the go-to spot for developers to implement custom sales order checks, validations, and logic.

At one client, a senior developer proudly said, ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve been using MV45AFZZ for 15 years, and it works just fine. Why change?‚Äù

And he wasn‚Äôt wrong. In many ways, that‚Äôs a Level B extensibility choice: small, controlled, and serving the business well. (In fact, SAP even documented this in SAP Note 3578329, proving that not all ‚Äòold-school‚Äô practices are bad.)

The problem comes when dozens of such exits pile up, undocumented, with overlapping logic ‚Äî and suddenly the system feels like a house of cards.

Here‚Äôs the twist: ABCD extensibility is not about banning MV45AFZZ or exits. It‚Äôs about putting them in the right place, with the right intent.

The IDoc Question: Clean or Not?

One of the most common debates I hear is: ‚ÄúWe use IDocs everywhere. Are they clean core?‚Äù

The answer: Yes, IDocs are safe ‚Äî they fall under Level B.

SAP clarified this in the IDoc Clean Core blog.

Why? Because IDocs are:

  • Officially documented.
  • Supported by SAP.
  • Used for integration and still relevant in S/4HANA.

That said, if you‚Äôre starting a greenfield cloud project, you may want to move toward APIs and Event Mesh (Level A) instead. But if you‚Äôve got an existing landscape with IDocs, don‚Äôt panic ‚Äî they‚Äôre not ‚Äúunclean.‚Äù

Real-World Scenarios: Which Level to Choose?

Why This Matters for AI

AI copilots like Joule don‚Äôt ‚Äúguess.‚Äù They rely on:

  • Stable APIs (Level A).
  • Clear data models (A & B).
  • Trusted logic (not buried in Level C/D).

If your system is full of Level D hacks, AI copilots won‚Äôt understand your processes. But if you steer toward A and B (with C monitored), you create an AI-ready enterprise.

 Closing Thought

Extensibility is not the villain. Misuse is.

The ABCD framework gives us a shared language:

  • A when we want innovation + AI without worry.
  • B when proven frameworks like IDocs or MV45AFZZ still serve us.
  • C only if there‚Äôs no choice ‚Äî and we track it closely.
  • D only if we want to leave a headache for the next generation.

So next time someone says ‚Äúlet‚Äôs customize,‚Äù you don‚Äôt need to panic. You just need to ask:

Is this A, B, C, or D? And that one question can mean the difference between a system that blocks AI ‚Äî and one that accelerates it.

#SAPCleanCore #SAPExtensibility #ABAPCloud #SAPAI #SAPBTP #S4HANACloud #IDoc

entry.title: DIY JDBC Sender Adapter for SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
DIY JDBC Sender Adapter for SAP Integration Suite

Introduction

Are you migrating from SAP PO to Integration Suite and missing the JDBC Sender Adapter for various integration scenarios? If so, I have just the solution for you! In this article I will show you, how to simulate a JDBC Sender Adapter using a smart design approach. My method allows both scheduled and manual triggering (without redeploying your IFlow). I'll guide you step by step through my implementation to enable you to do the same on your use case.

Core Insight

You can simulate a JDBC Sender Adapter by configuring the Request/Reply step and incorporating your needed triggers.

My Step-by-Step Implementation

Entire Integration Process

Part 1: Polling and Decoupling 

  1. Scheduler & Manual Polling

    • I created two entry points for the integration flow:
      • A configurable scheduler for periodic database polls.
      • An HTTP endpoint for manual polling via Postman GET‚Äîperfect for testing or urgent triggers.
  2. Manual and Scheduled Fetch ProcessPolling the Sender DB
  • Used a local subprocess with a Request/Reply step to fetch data from the source database.
  • The fetched data is safely written to a DataStore or a JMS Queue (choose what suits your tenant/scenario) for decoupling and most importantly(at least for me): Retry handling.
SELECT * FROM ${property.JDBC_Schema}.${property.JDBC_Table};

JDBC Poll Process

Part 2: Mapping and Writing to Target DB

Write Data to Target

 

  1. Reading from DataStore/JMS Queue
    • In a second integration process, the data is read from the queue or store.
    • Exchange the sender adapter as needed.
  2. Message Mapping in a Local Subprocess
    • I placed mapping logic inside a local subprocess to isolate errors.
    • If mapping fails, it sets a custom status MappingFailed. 
    • Mapping errors cannot be retried, so the message escalates directly.
      local Mapping Process
  3. Insert into Target DB
    • After a successful mapping, data is inserted into the target database.

Error Handling

  • Errors are sent to a global error handling process, which checks the Nr of retries against the configured max and then yields an end event.
    • Automatic retries is triggered with an Error End.
    • Max retries reached, the message was sent to a Dead Letter Queue (DataStore) and escalates.
      Retry Handling Process
  • Mapping errors escalate instantly. They need to be resolved manually. 

Recommendations for Integration Developers

  • Decouple processes using DataStore or JMS Queue; which makes error handling and retries much easier.
  • Design your flow to be manually triggerable (e.g., via Postman or another IFlow) which comes in handy in an error case or for testing.

Personal Reflection

Honestly, I was surprised at how well this workaround performed, especially in terms of error handling and decoupling. While it‚Äôs not as plug-and-play as a native JDBC Sender Adapter in PO, I created a "template" IFlow based on this concept that I can reuse wherever needed. I have already migrated multiple scenarios using this approach, and it is almost as plug-and-play as in SAP PO. If you are interested in the template or have any questions regarding this topic, feel free to contact me!

SAP Integration Suite

entry.title: Master Blog: SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite Migration ‚Äì Tool and Guidance
entry.content:
Migration Journey Overview: From Assessment to Tooling

Migrating from SAP Process Orchestration to the SAP Integration Suite represents a significant milestone in your organization‚Äôs cloud transformation journey. This master blog serves as a central hub for comprehensive information and guidance related to the Migration Tool and the broader migration process. It provides links to detailed blogs, documentation, and best practices to help you successfully plan and execute your migration to SAP Integration Suite.

Before beginning any migration activity, it‚Äôs crucial to start with the Migration Assessment - a key capability of the SAP Integration Suite. The assessment analyses your on-premises landscape, including existing integration configurations, mappings, custom adapters, and dependent objects. It provides detailed insights and a comprehensive overview indicating which scenarios can be migrated as-is, which ones require optimization, and which may need to be redesigned or modernized. This step establishes a clear, data-driven foundation for a successful and efficient migration journey.

Once your Migration Assessment is complete, the next big step is moving your integration content to the cloud - and that‚Äôs where the Migration Tool comes into play!

The Migration Tool, built into SAP Integration Suite‚Äôs Cloud Integration capability, helps you bring your existing integration scenarios from SAP Process Orchestration to the cloud with ease. Think of it as your Guided workflow for migration - it identifies what can be moved, converts integration artifacts into their cloud-ready counterparts, and helps you streamline the entire process with minimal manual effort.

Migration Tool ‚Äì Offerings and Supported Components

The Migration Tool comes packed with a set of features to make your move from SAP Process Orchestration to the SAP Integration Suite smoother and faster. Here‚Äôs an overview of the key components it supports and automates.

Connectivity to On-Premise Systems: Choose the appropriate connection setup for securely linking your on-premise landscape with the SAP Integration Suite. For detailed configuration options, see Configuring Connectivity to an SAP Process Orchestration System

Object Types: The tool supports migration of integration artifacts such as Integrated Configurations, which define how messages are processed within the Java-only runtime of SAP Process Orchestration systems.

It also supports Receiver Determination, which is available in SAP Process Integration dual-stack installations (from release 7.5 onwards) where message processing takes place on both ABAP and Java stacks.

 

Patterns: The Migration Tool supports a variety of integration patterns to help you transition your existing scenarios to cloud-ready designs. These patterns provide flexibility for different integration needs - whether it‚Äôs point-to-point communication, content-based routing, or complex orchestration flows.

For the complete list of supported patterns, refer to the Migration Patterns

Migration Approaches: The Migration Tool offers two approaches - Standard Approach and Pipeline Approach to help you move your integration scenarios efficiently to the cloud. For more details, see Pipeline Concept

 

Communication Channels: The Migration Tool helps move your existing communication channels to the cloud, making sure your integration endpoints and related settings are mapped correctly. A few exceptions may apply, so some channels might need minor adjustments after migration. For more details, see Standard Adapter Migration.

Adapter Module Support: The tool automatically migrates PGP encryption and decryption modules to cloud-compatible configurations. Additional adapter modules are provided through the community package and can be leveraged as needed. The following list provides an overview: Adapter Modules

Decoupling and Ordered Message Processing with JMS Queues: The Migration Tool supports JMS queue configurations to enable decoupled communication between senders and receivers. In SAP Integration Suite Cloud Integration, internal JMS Adapter help separate asynchronous message processing from the sender, allowing messages to be handled independently and reliably.

To ensure messages are processed in the correct order - EOIO, the Access Type should be set to Exclusive, which ensures that only one consumer/worker processes messages from the queue at a time.

Note: This configuration is not applied automatically by the Migration Tool and must be set manually.

Idempotent at Receiver: The tool also provides idempotent message handling at the receiver side. This means it helps prevent duplicate message processing, ensuring that each message is delivered and processed only once - an essential feature for maintaining data consistency.

Reusing Artifacts for Efficient Migration: The Migration Tool provides options for users to reuse existing standalone artifacts - message mappings and function libraries, to their migrated scenarios. This flexibility allows message mappings and other artifacts to be reused across multiple integration scenarios, reducing redundancy and speeding up the migration process.

Example: Enable Reusable Artifacts

 

Migration Summary: After the migration, a detailed summary report provides an overview of all successfully migrated Integration Flow Configurations and their related objects in the cloud. If any object could not be migrated, this information is clearly highlighted in the summary, helping you identify follow-up actions easily.

The Migration Tool does offer a downloadable Summary Report that captures essential migration details - including the on-premise system details, integration patterns used, chosen migration approach, and other key information related to each migrated object, which you can review later if required.

Note: If you‚Äôd like to select an alternative runtime profile instead of the default Cloud Integration, you can manually set it in the Integration Runtime configuration after the successful migration of the Integration Flow.

Error Logs: When the Migration Tool cannot migrate to certain integration scenarios, it generates a detailed error log summary. This log provides insights into the specific issues encountered, helping you understand what went wrong and take corrective actions.

Hint: The error log is available to download as a .csv file. You can import it in Excel and use a delimiter as Comma (,) to transform the data, to review and analyse the migration errors effectively check columns ‚ÄòStatus‚Äô and ‚ÄòMessage‚Äô.

 

For detailed, step-by-step instructions on using the Migration Tool, refer to the official tutorial: Use the Migration Tooling

 

Known Limitations of the Migration Tool

While the Migration Tool covers a wide range of integration scenarios, there are some known gaps and limitations. For the most up-to-date information, refer to Known Limitations of Migration Tooling 

Disclaimer: The list of gaps and limitations may shorten as SAP expands coverage and implements features on its roadmap

 

Next in the Series

Stay tuned for the upcoming posts where we will dive deeper into specific migration scenarios, tips, and best practices to help you get the most out of SAP Integration Suite.

Published:

‚úÖ Migrating Point-to-Point Asynchronous Scenarios Using the Migration Tool in SAP Integration Suite

‚úÖ Migrating XSLT mappings from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite 

 

Up Next:

‚û°Ô∏èMigrating Content-Based Routing Scenarios Using the Migration Tool in SAP Integration Suite

 

 

References - SAP Documentation and Blogs:

Migration Guide for SAP Process Orchestration

Get Started with Migration to SAP Integration Suite

Assessment Blog: How to use the Migration Assessment Application to get ready to migrate your SAP Process Orchestration Scenarios?

Migration Tool: Migration tool in Cloud Integration Capability of SAP Integration Suite

entry.title: How to Implement Dynamic Throttling in SAP CPI Using Groovy Script
entry.content:
Introduction:

Managing API rate restrictions or avoiding backend system overloads are common problems in SAP Cloud Integration (CPI). When an API receives too many requests in a short period of time, some may reject them, while others may experience significant slowdowns.

In this post, I will demonstrate how to create a dynamic delay mechanism in CPI using Groovy Script, where the sleep duration varies according to request count(header value).

Problem Statement:

  • Rate-limiting is often necessary for backend or API services.
  • Standard CPI configuration does not offer a built-in dynamic sleep/throttle feature.
  • When the load increases, developers need a lightweight way to decrease request speeds.

Solution Approach:

We can use a Groovy Script in CPI to:

1 .Read a custom header (SAP_ApplicationID in this case).

2. Transform it into an integer request count.

3. Implement adaptive delay logic with different thresholds.

Proceed with processing after the determined sleep duration.

//Groovy script
import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;
 
def Message processData(Message message) {
 
    def body = message.getBody();
 
    // Read SAP_ApplicationID
    def headerValue = message.getHeader("SAP_ApplicationID", String.class);
    def requestCount = 0;
 
    if (headerValue != null) {
        try {
            requestCount = headerValue.toInteger();
        } catch (Exception e) {
            requestCount = 0; // Default if not a number
        }
    }
 
    // Determine sleep time 
    def sleepTime = 0;
    if (requestCount >= 3500) {
        sleepTime = 1500;
    } else if (requestCount >= 2000) {
        sleepTime = 1000;
    } else if (requestCount >= 1000) {
        sleepTime = 500;
    } else if (requestCount >= 500) {
        sleepTime = 200;
    } else if (requestCount < 500) {
        sleepTime = 100;
    }
 
    // Apply sleep delay
    if (sleepTime > 0) {
        sleep(sleepTime);
    }
 
    message.setBody(body);
    return message;
}

How it works :

Step 1: Get SAP_ApplicationID from headers.

Step 2: Convert it into an integer(requestCount).

Step 3: Decide sleep time dynamically:

  •  ‚â• 3500 - 1500 ms
  •  ‚â• 2000 - 1000 ms 
  •  ‚â• 1000 - 500 ms
  •  ‚â• 500 - 200 ms
  •  < 500 - 100 ms

Step 4: Sleep for calculated time.

Step 5: Pass the original message forward.

Use cases:

1. For high-frequency situations, API rate restriction with shorter delays works perfectly.

2. Backend overload protection with millisecond-level throttling.

3. Testing integrations under various load conditions.

Conclusion:

This Groovy script provides a simple but effective way to dynamically throttle requests in SAP CPI based on header values. By introducing adaptive delays, you can protect backend systems, comply with API rate limits, and simulate controlled load behaviour.

entry.title: Integration Between SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere (JDBC Connection)
entry.content:
Integration Between SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere (JDBC Connection)

JDBC ‚Äì JAVA DATABASE CONNECTIVITY

Why Recommendation for JDBC Over OData API :
JDBC is recommended over OData when consuming large-scale records (e.g., 100,000+) because JDBC streams data directly from the database with better performance and less overhead, while OData is optimized for lightweight, paginated, service-based access.

Problem statement: 3337495 - OData API returns less records than expected due paging
Pagination limits in OData and Ariba APIs can be handled in SAP CPI using a looping process call. I‚Äôll cover this with a clear explanation in an upcoming post.

Goal: Connect CPI to a database used by DataSphere (JDBC) and run a simple read data from the (Analytical Model / Table /View).

For the Write / Delete / Update method, the attached SAP Help Portal Link has syntax in the reference section.

Prerequisites:

  1. SAP DataSphere ‚Äì Subscribed account (‚ö† Trial has limited features, JDBC not supported)
  2. SAP Integration Suite ‚Äì Subscribed or Trial (JDBC actions supported)

 

SAP DataSphere Step by Step Guide :

Step

Action / Notes

1. Create a Space

DataSphere ‚Üí Space Management ‚Üí New Space ‚Üí Name it ‚Üí Create.

2. Create Table / Analytical Model

Data Builder ‚Üí In your Space ‚Üí New ‚Üí Table or Analytical Model ‚Üí define fields & data types ‚Üí Save & Publish.
*Verify Table/Model Deployed Successfully. *

3. Prepare / Load Data

Load data manually for testing cases. Otherwise load CSV/import to table via Data Builder/Data Integration.

4. Note Schema & Object Names

Record schema name, table name, and view names for JDBC SQL use.
* Created space name is the SCHEMA name and Collect Table / Model name *

5. Decide Where to Create DB User

If HANA Cloud ‚Üí use HANA Cockpit/DB Explorer. If on-prem DB ‚Üí use DB admin tools or contact DB Admin.
* We are using the HANA cloud system for practical session*

6. Create JDBC DB User

DB admin tool ‚Üí Security/Users ‚Üí New User ‚Üí set username & strong password ‚Üí Save.
*Check Active status of User*

7. Grant Privileges for the DB user

Assign only required privileges (e.g., SELECT for read; add INSERT/UPDATE/DELETE for CRUD). Best practice: create role JDBC_ROLE and assign.

8. Prepare JDBC Connection Details

Gather JDBC URL (e.g.  sample URL from datasphere: z*********-abc.hana.prod-eu10.hanacloud.ondemand.com
Format for CPI JDBC Material:
jdbc:sap://<host>:<port>/?encrypt=true&validateCertificate=true


SAP Integration Suite Step by Step Guide :

Create a Package & Artifact

  • In CPI ‚Üí Design ‚Üí Create a new package ‚Üí Add an integration flow artifact.
  • ‚úÖ Make sure your CPI user has the required roles to create and access design-time artifacts.

Go to Monitoring ‚Üí JDBC Material

  • In CPI ‚Üí Monitor ‚Üí Integrations and APIs ‚Üí Manage Security ‚Üí JDBC Material

     

  • ‚Üí Add JDBC Data Source. ‚Üí Select HANA cloud

     



  • Provide JDBC URL in the correct format (e.g., jdbc:sap://<hana-host>:443/?encrypt=true&validateCertificate=true).

     

  • Enter DB username and password (use the dedicated JDBC user created earlier in DataSphere).

     

  • Save and deploy the JDBC material.

Apply JDBC Material in iFlow

  • In your integration flow, configure the JDBC receiver adapter ‚Üí select the JDBC data source created.
  • Use SQL queries (SELECT) in the Processing tab or provide XML query body. Here, I‚Äôm using SQL SELECT * to fetch all records from the table.

 


Step 1: Timer Start
 In this iFlow, the Start Timer is configured with a Simple Schedule ‚Üí None ‚Üí On Deployment, which means the integration flow automatically triggers immediately after deployment.

 


Step 2: Content Modifier
Use this SQL query to fetch all records with the body operation.
 SELECT * FROM "<Schema>"."<Model/TableName>"

 



Step 3: Request Reply & JDBC Receiver Adapter
 ‚Üí Use the deployed JDBC Data Source alias in the JDBC Material in the previous step and set Max records count based on your requirement.
‚Üí JDBC Maximum Records per call:  2,147,483,647

 


Sample data Response from JDBC Connection:

References :
same blog by me for clear picture quality: Integration of SAP CPI and SAP DataSphere using JD... - SAP Community
CPI JDBC ‚Äì XML Query in Body for CRUD Operations (Syntax Guide)
 link:
https://help.sap.com/docs/cloud-integration/sap-cloud-integration/payload-and-operation

entry.title: ABAP Proxy generation support with SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

ABAP Proxies are one of the most widely used integration technologies in SAP landscapes. For years, they have been central to PI/PO-based integrations. Now, with the availability of ABAP Proxy support in SAP Integration Suite, customers can extend this capability to the cloud, accelerating their migration from PI/PO to Integration Suite. This closes an important gap for organizations transitioning from SAP Process Integration (PI/PO) to SAP Integration Suite .

This blog provides a technical overview and step-by-step setup guide for enabling generation of ABAP Proxies with Integration Suite.

What Are ABAP Proxies?

  • ABAP Proxies are generated classes in the SAP ABAP system based on service interfaces defined in the Enterprise Service Repository (ESR).

  • They allow ABAP developers to call or expose services without dealing with low-level communication protocols.

  • Proxies are commonly used for synchronous/asynchronous service calls, typically via SOAP adapters in PI/PO.

Why ABAP Proxy Support in SAP Integration Suite Matters?

Until recently, ABAP proxies were heavily tied to on-premise PI/PO middleware. With many customers moving their integration  to the cloud, there was a strong demand for equivalent support in Integration Suite.

Key benefits of the new support include:

  • Cloud-first Enablement ‚Äì Seamlessly connect SAP backends to Integration Suite using proxies.
  • Reuse of Existing Investments ‚Äì No need to redesign all integration scenarios; existing service interfaces can still be leveraged.
  • Simplified Migration from PI/PO ‚Äì Reduces the complexity of moving from legacy middleware to cloud-based integration.
  • Standardized Integration ‚Äì Continue using ESR artifacts and ABAP proxies as standardized communication interfaces.

Prerequisites

  • SAP Integration Suite tenant is active.
  • Connectivity between SAP backend and Integration Suite (HTTPS) is enabled.
  • Certificates (for mutual TLS if required) are exchanged.
  • Service interface meant for proxy generation must already be present/imported inside an Integration Package of the  SAP Integration Suite tenant
  • You've a user with the role  AuthGroup_IntegrationDeveloper assigned.

Connectivity between SAP backend and Integration Suite

For ABAP Proxy to Integration Suite, the standard practice is to configure an SM59 destination of type G.

SM59 Destination Configuration (Type G) :

Configuration Steps in SM59 (Type G)

Go to Transaction SM59

Choose HTTP Connections to External Server.

Create a new destination  or Open the existing Destination with name SAP_PROXY_ESR 

Technical Settings

  • Target Host: The host name of Integration Suite tenant(Navigate to BTP Cockpit  Instances and Subscriptions  < your instance for Service Process Integration Runtime with api Plan> View Credentials (in JSON format) and copy the url(without https://)  Note : Do not use the clientId and client secret from the Service Key instance

  • Service No.: 443 (for HTTPS).
  • Path Prefix: Enter the following : /rest/api/v1/workspace/sproxy 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Logon & Security

  • Choose Basic Authentication
  • Enter the credentials of the Technical user  with role AuthGroup_IntegrationDeveloper assigned and created with Default Identity Provider
  • Security Options
    • Select SSL Active
    • Import CPI‚Äôs Server certificate into transaction STRUST (SSL Client ‚Üí Standard).
    • Assign it to the relevant SSL Client PSE so that HTTPS trust is established

  • Save the changes and Perform Connection Test. Successful Connection Test result in HTTP 200 Ok Response .

 

 

 

 

 

 

Procedure to Generate ABAP Proxy

  • Log into the SAP ABAP backend system (ECC or S/4HANA).
  • Run transaction SPROXY.
    • This transaction allows browsing and generating proxies from  Service Interfaces present in the Integration Suite tenant that is configured in SM59 destination(SAP_PROXY_ESR)
    • In the Enterprise Service Browser view, navigate to Source --> ESR --> SWCs  to see the list of Integration Packages that contain atleast one of the proxy relevant artifacts(Datatypes,(Fault)Message Types,Service Interfaces) are listed.
    • Locate the Integration Package containing the desired Service Interface (Inbound or Outbound).
    • Drill down to Service Provider or Service Consumer.(Namespaces -->Choose the desire namespace -->Object Types)
    • Choose the Inbound (server proxy) or Outbound (client proxy) interface.
    • Right-click the selected Service Provider or Consumer ‚Üí choose Generate.
    • Proxy Generation Wizard opens. Provide:
    • Prefix for ABAP Class Names (if needed).
    • Package assignment (should be a transportable package, not $TMP if moving to QA/Prod).
    • Transport request for recording the generated objects.
    • The system creates ABAP proxy classes:
      • Inbound Server Proxy ‚Üí ABAP Class implementing the interface with predefined methods (developer writes business logic here).
      • Outbound Client Proxy ‚Üí ABAP Class to call external services (system generates methods to call the remote service).
      • Supporting DDIC structures, types, and message interfaces are also generated.
      • Save and Activate the generated proxies

Use the  generated proxy class to implement the Business logic  in Transaction SE80 or SE24 .

Current Limitations in the SPROXY Navigation Tree :

  • Folders are not visible in the SPROXY navigation tree
  • Datatype enhancements are not listed.
  • Classifications and Matching Service Interface details will be missing in the Proxy Editor of the Service Interface
  • ...

Recommended view to be used - Enterprise Services Browser view.

Also please ensure to import the service interfaces and its dependants to the Integration Suite tenant from the PI/PO ESR system that was earlier configured in SM 59 destination to be able to retain the already generated proxies. Try maintaining SWCV  to Integration Package mapping i.e. Avoid importing objects from multiple SWCV's to one Integration Packages.. Avoid having objects with same name and namespace in multiple Integration Packages.

entry.title: Migrating Point-to-Point Asynchronous Scenarios Using the Migration Tool in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
This blog post is part of the series Master Blog: SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite Migration ‚Äì Tool and Guidance exploring how to migrate various integration patterns from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite using the Migration Tool. In this blog, we will focus on the Point-to-Point (P2P) Asynchronous pattern, which is one of the most common and fundamental integration scenarios.

 

Objective

The goal of this blog is to explain how the Migration Tool supports P2P asynchronous integrations, including:

  • Key configuration options and technical considerations
  • Best practices to ensure reliable and decoupled communication
  • How to implement JMS decoupling and Idempotent Processing effectively

 

Understanding the Point-to-Point Asynchronous Pattern

In a Point-to-Point (P2P) asynchronous integration, a message is sent from a sender to a receiver without a response message. This pattern promotes decoupling between systems, improves reliability, and allows retry mechanisms to ensure delivery in case you are using JMS queues. By default, the Migration Tool will enable JMS queues during migration.

If there are constraints on the limit of available JMS queues, the tool also supports direct communication without JMS, though this reduces decoupling and resilience. If you are migrating a high number of asynchronous interfaces, SAP recommends using the pipeline approach, which will not be covered in this blog. You can find more information in Pipeline Concept and  Migration Tooling now supporting migration via the pipeline approach.

 

Migration Tool Support for P2P Asynchronous Scenarios using Standard Approach

The Migration Tool automates most of the effort by generating a ready-to-use Integration Flow (iFlow) and the corresponding configuration objects in SAP Cloud Integration.

Depending on your settings, the tool can generate Integration Flows that:

1. Decouple with JMS Queue: Use JMS queues for decoupling between sender and receiver systems (only shown for Asynchronous interfaces):

When you select this option, the Migration Tool creates two Integration Processes within the generated iFlow:

  • Inbound Process
    • Receives the message from the migrated Sender Component and Communication Channel
    • Forwards the message to the JMS queue
  • Outbound Process
    • Reads the message from the JMS queue
    • Performs any required processing (e.g., message mapping, data transformation)

Delivers the message to the receiver system

Please note that you need to maintain the name of the JMS queue post-migration using the already created external parameters:

2. Idempotent Process at the Receiver Side: Use the idempotent process call if you want to make sure that the message will be delivered exactly once to the target system:

When you select this option, the generated iFlow will include an Idempotent Process Call. This mechanism ensures that a message is delivered exactly once to the receiver system, avoiding duplicate postings.

The API call at the receiver system is wrapped then into this local integration process.

There are receiver adapters that do supports idempotency such as SOAP RM, XI and IDoc. In these cases, it‚Äôs preferable that you don‚Äôt use the Idempotent option on Migration Tool and choose to handle it directly in the adapter. You can find more information in Special Use Cases: SAP RM vs XI vs IDoc.

 

Post-Migration Activities and Special Scenarios

While the Migration Tool significantly accelerates the transition from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite, a few manual fine-tuning steps are typically required.

Generic Post-Migration Steps

After migrating a P2P Asynchronous interface:

  1. Review and update external parameters for sender and receiver connectivity.
  2. Define the JMS queue name to be used in both Integration Processes (in case checkbox is marked during wizard). This can be done in the external parameters‚Äô configuration view.
  3. Update
  4. Review if you want to change the value of the header SAP_Sender according to the naming convention that will be adopted on SAP Integration Suite.

Manual Activities Depending on Integration Scenario

You can also find below few examples of manual activities post-migration that needs to be performed depending on the content of your integration scenario:

  1. Functions like RFC Lookup or JDBC Lookup on Graphical Message Mapping are not automatically converted. Replace them with equivalent Integration Suite adapters or externalized APIs. Tutorials are available for JDBC lookups and RFC lookups.
  2. If your interface is using any custom code (e.g., UDF, Function Library, Java Mapping) or XSLT that have additional dependencies, Therefore, you need to export them from SAP Process Orchestration and import into your Integration Flow
  3. If your interface is using a fault message handling, this won‚Äôt be migrated using the Migration Tool. Therefore, you need to import the mapping using the standalone functionality and add an exception handling subprocess into the migrated iFlow

Please refer to the Known Limitations of Migration Tooling for additional insights into cases that may require manual adjustments after migration. we will explore specific topics in more depth, such as XSLT transformation differences between SAP Process Orchestration and SAP Integration Suite, custom code migration, fault message handling, and other advanced migration scenarios.

 

Async-Sync Bridge Support

The Point-to-Point Asynchronous pattern also covers scenarios using an Async-Sync bridge.

In SAP Process Orchestration, an asynchronous interface is converted into synchronous using the RequestResponseBean module, enabling a response message to be sent back to the sender asynchronously using a second interface object.

The Migration Tool can migrate this Async-Sync bridge scenario as well, ensuring that both asynchronous and synchronous steps are merged into a single iFlow.

Please note that the Sync-Async bridge scenario (the opposite from the above), is not supported as of today.

 

Conclusion

In this first blog of the blog series, we explored how to migrate Point-to-Point Asynchronous scenarios and how the Migration Tool simplifies this process by leveraging JMS decoupling and Idempotent Processing. These capabilities help ensure reliable, scalable, and fault-tolerant communication between systems.

entry.title: Partnering for Progress: Accelerate Your Move to SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
When I first started working with SAP‚Äôs Migration Factory program, I quickly realized just how big of a shift many organizations were facing.
For years, SAP Process Integration (PI) and SAP Process Orchestration (PO) have been the backbone of countless businesses‚Äô integration landscapes. But with mainstream maintenance ending in 2027, the question everyone‚Äôs asking is: ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs next?‚Äù

And the answer is clear ‚Äî SAP Integration Suite on SAP Business Technology Platform (BTP).
It‚Äôs modern, scalable, and built to meet the needs of today‚Äôs connected, cloud-first world. But let‚Äôs be honest ‚Äî migration isn‚Äôt just about technology. It‚Äôs about people, collaboration, and having the right partners by your side.

That‚Äôs where Migration Factory 2.0 comes in.

Building a Stronger Ecosystem ‚Äî Together

What excites me most about Migration Factory 2.0 is that it‚Äôs not just a framework ‚Äî it‚Äôs a movement.
We‚Äôre bringing together SAP and our partners under one unified goal: to help customers modernize with speed, confidence, and shared expertise.

Through this program, partners get the enablement and resources they need to deliver migrations effectively, and customers get access to a trusted ecosystem that‚Äôs been trained, certified, and supported directly by SAP.

It‚Äôs truly a ‚Äúwin-win-win‚Äù ‚Äî for SAP, our partners, and most importantly, our customers.

Behind the Program: Enablement, Execution, and Engagement

At its core, Migration Factory 2.0 is built on three simple but powerful pillars:

  • Enablement: We equip partners with the latest training, certifications, and migration tooling ‚Äî including our Integration Suite Black Belt 2.0 program.

  • Execution: We support them with proven methodologies, automation frameworks, and best practices developed alongside SAP experts.

  • Engagement: We celebrate their success through co-marketing, events, and storytelling opportunities that amplify their impact across the SAP ecosystem.

Every one of these pillars is about empowering collaboration ‚Äî because success in integration isn‚Äôt achieved in isolation.

Why Partners Are the Game Changers

Working closely with our partners, I‚Äôve seen firsthand the dedication, innovation, and creativity they bring to every customer engagement.
Migration Factory 2.0 gives them more than just visibility ‚Äî it gives them a platform to shine.

Through the program, partners can:

  • Earn SAP‚Äôs Partner Badge for SAP PO/SAP Integration Suite Modernization

  • Be featured on our Migration Factory Partner Listing on SAP.com

  • Participate in co-marketing campaigns, webinars, and video series like Integration Situation

  • Receive qualified migration assessments from SAP

  • Connect with other partners and SAP experts through enablement sessions and community collaboration spaces

It‚Äôs inspiring to see how quickly our partner community has embraced this journey ‚Äî not just as a business opportunity, but as a shared mission to help customers move forward.

Helping Customers Choose the Right Partner

For customers, we‚Äôve made it easy to find the right expertise through the Migration Factory Partner Listing on SAP.com.
Each partner listed has been enabled through SAP‚Äôs framework and offers migration assessments, readiness checks, or implementation services tailored to customer needs.

Whether you‚Äôre in Europe, Asia, or North America ‚Äî you can now connect directly with a partner who understands your regional and industry-specific challenges.

My Favorite Part: The Collaboration

One of my favorite things about being part of this initiative is watching new partnerships form ‚Äî partners collaborating with each other, learning from SAP experts, and even co-creating new migration approaches together.
It‚Äôs a reminder that technology may power transformation, but people make it happen.

Every week, I see stories from partners who have taken what they learned from Migration Factory enablement sessions and turned it into real customer impact. That‚Äôs what keeps me passionate about this program ‚Äî it‚Äôs not theory, it‚Äôs transformation in action.

Let‚Äôs Move Forward ‚Äî Together

If you‚Äôre a partner, now‚Äôs the time to get involved.
Join the Migration Factory 2.0 program, earn your certifications, and showcase your success stories to the global SAP community.

If you‚Äôre a customer, explore the Migration Factory Partner Listing on SAP.com to connect with certified experts who can help you plan your move from SAP PI/PO to SAP Integration Suite.

The future of integration is here ‚Äî and it‚Äôs collaborative, connected, and cloud-driven.
Together, we‚Äôre accelerating integration modernization ‚Äî one connection at a time.

entry.title: High-Volume Data Handling in SAP Integration Suite - Our Journey to 10 Million Records
entry.content:
‚ÄúIn the middle of difficulty lies opportunity.‚Äù ‚Äì Albert Einstein

Handling large-volume data integration is something every integration specialist meets sooner or later. Recently, our team faced one of those ‚Äúopportunities‚Äù‚Äîa requirement to transfer around 10 million records from a source system to a target application using SAP Integration Suite (IS) formerly called as SAP Cloud Platform Integration (CPI).

At first glance, the mapping requirements were straightforward. But as always, the devil hides in the details: the pagination behavior of the OData V4 adapter, the Integration Suite processing limits, and unforeseen behavioral quirks pushed us through several attempts before landing on a robust solution.

This blog walks through:

  • What approaches we tried
  • Why they failed
  • What finally worked
  • Key learnings for anyone building high-volume integrations on SAP IS

Context: The Scenario

The source system exposed data through an OData V4 service. A key limitation we discovered early on:

  • Pagination is fully server-controlled in OData V4 adapter
  • The page size cannot be customized in SAP Integration Suite (e.g., you cannot set it to 1,000 or 10,000) when using the standard OData V4 adapter, it always respects the server-side limit
  • Example: If the server page size is 50,000, SAP IS will always retrieve chunks of 50,000 - nothing less

This limitation became the center of the problem.

Approach 1 ‚Äî Standard OData V4 Adapter + Looping Process Call

(Expected to work‚Ä¶ reality had other plans)

How it worked:

  • Used the OData V4 adapter as-is with server-side pagination
  • Used Looping Process Call to iterate through pages

What happened:

  • If the total data was below 50K, everything worked smoothly
  • Above 50K, the iFlow got stuck in Processing
  • No errors
  • No termination
  • Messages remained frozen for days

Example:

  • Server page size ‚Üí 50K
  • Data set = 40K ‚Üí Success
  • Data set = 150K ‚Üí iFlow stalled indefinitely

Lesson: Looping + uncontrolled server pagination = unpredictable behavior.

Approach 2 ‚Äî OData V4 Adapter + Custom Pagination Logic

(Better‚Ä¶ but still not scalable enough)

This time we added:

  • Custom counter checks
  • Pagination logic in iFlow
  • Looping until full completion

Result:

  • Worked better than Approach 1
  • Successfully processed volumes under ~1 million records
  • Beyond that threshold ‚Üí iFlow stuck again, still showing Processing but not progressing
  • No runtime error, no bottleneck in MPL ‚Äî simply a silent stall

Lesson: The bottleneck was structural, not logical.

Approach 3 ‚Äî Final Working Solution (and the hero of the story)

‚ÄúSimplicity is the ultimate sophistication.‚Äù ‚Äî Leonardo da Vinci

Key idea:

Avoid OData V4 adapter entirely.

Use the Classic HTTP Adapter with explicit control over pagination (via top & skip).

This allowed us to fully control the data fetch size and execution flow.

Our Winning Architecture

Flow 1: Master Controller iFlow

  1. Call the source system via HTTP adapter
  2. Retrieve total record count
  3. Calculate the required number of batches
    • Batch size = server-side max (e.g., 50K)
  4. For each batch, create a message containing only the skip value
  5. Store skip values in Data Store

Example:

Total records = 1,000,000
Batch size = 50,000
Total batches = 20
Stored skip values = 0, 50000, 100000, ...


Flow 2: Worker iFlow

  1. Poll Data Store
  2. Read skip value
  3. Call API using HTTP adapter with parameters:
    $top=50000
    $skip=<value from datastore>
  4. Process the dataset
  5. Deliver to target system

The Big Win

This mechanism:

  • Gave us full control over pagination
  • Completely bypassed OData V4 limitations
  • Handled 10+ MILLION records without stalls
  • Achieved stable throughput
  • No permanent IFlow ‚ÄúProcessing‚Äù states
  • No invisible bottlenecks

Lesson: If the adapter limits you, take control with HTTP.

Key Learnings

  • SAP Integration Suite is powerful and evolving, but very high-volume scenarios still expose adapter-level limitations
  • OData V4 Adapter may not be suitable for massive pagination-driven extractions in all cases
  • HTTP adapter with custom pagination is a reliable fallback
  • Sometimes the ‚Äúclassic‚Äù tool is the best tool

And yes‚Äîraising an SAP incident might eventually clarify the root cause, but business timelines forced us to engineer a workaround.

Conclusion

High-volume data integration is never trivial. The key is to experiment, observe system behavior, and design around limitations. Our final approach was not just functional‚Äîit was scalable, predictable, and production-proof.

If you‚Äôre dealing with similar large dataset transfers in SAP IS, this solution pattern might save you hours of troubleshooting.

Feedback Welcome

I‚Äôd love to hear your thoughts, improvements, or other patterns you‚Äôve successfully used for large-volume integration scenarios in SAP Integration Suite.

Thank you for reading!

I2Integration Solutions | A Startup

Connect in LinkedIn: I2Integrate

entry.title: Migrating XSLT mappings from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
This blog post is part of the series Master Blog: SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite Migration ‚Äì Tool and Guidance exploring how to migrate various integration patterns from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite using the Migration Tool. In this blog, we will explore the migration process of XSLT mappings.   

While SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration supports XSLT mappings, you may encounter subtle yet impactful differences when migrating XSLT-based mappings from SAP Process Orchestration (PO). This post outlines the main variations between both environments, explains typical runtime issues, and provides practical guidance for smooth adaptation.

 

XSLT Processor Differences 

The XSLT processor behind Cloud Integration is Saxon EE 9.9.1.6 (as of November 2025 ‚Äì see this Blog for details on verifying the processor version) while SAP Process Orchestration next to its default allowed the import and use of other processors. 

While these differences should not usually cause major compatibility problems, certain manual adjustments after the tool-assisted migration might be required to deploy or execute mappings successfully. In particular, there are variations in how standard XSLT functions handle data types, how Java classes are used within XSLT code and how other stylesheets are included. 

 

Data Type Handling in XSLT Functions 

SAP Process Orchestration tends to be more lenient regarding data type usage in standard XSLT functions. Cloud Integration, on the other hand, applies stricter type validation during compilation and runtime. 

Example 1: Using xsl:sort with Data Types 

The xsl:sort function sorts data based on specified criteria: 

<xsl:sort select="data" data-type="text"/> 

The allowed data types for this function are "text" and "number". On SAP Process Orchestration, the following syntax works without error: 

<xsl:sort select="DATES" order="ascending" data-type="xsd:Date"/> 

However, in Cloud Integration this causes a runtime error: 

Adjusting the data-type accordingly to text or number solves this issue. However, one needs to pay attention to the effects this might have on the format and thus the rest of the stylesheet execution. 

 

Example 2: Using format-number() with non-numeric inputs 

On SAP Process Orchestration, the following syntax works without error: 

<xsl:value-of select="format-number(substring(data, 0, 3), '0.00')"/> 

In Cloud Integration, this causes a compilation error during runtime: 

The issue arises because format-number() requires a numeric input, while substring() returns a string. 
To resolve this, explicitly convert the substring to a number: 

<xsl:value-of select="format-number(number(substring(data, 0, 3)), '0.00')"/> 

Please note that if a global number format is defined, this conversion might affect the formatting of the substring according to that global setting. 

 

Using Java Classes in XSLT 

XSLT mappings sometimes rely on custom Java classes to extend the functionality of native XSLT functions, a common practice in integration projects where XSLT offered fewer built-in capabilities.  

During migration, you may encounter Java classes ranging from simple helpers (e.g., string or date transformations, counters) to more complex ones (e.g., document loaders, RFC calls, or value mapping lookups). While some advanced use cases may require redesign or alternative approaches, simpler helper classes can still be used in Cloud Integration. 

Step 1: Uploading the Java Classes 

Upload the Java classes as a JAR file and add them to the iFlow‚Äôs References (using the Archive option). 

If the java classes are contained in the same Imported Archive (IA) as the XSLT using them on PO, the migration tool will automatically import them as it imports the entire IA during the migration process. However, if the java classes are in a separate IA, this needs to be done manually post tool migration. 

Please note that the JAR file must be added as a local resource into the iFlow. Currently it‚Äôs not possible to use as a reusable artifact. 

Step 2: Adjusting XSLT Syntax 

 

  1. Namespace Declarations 

SAP Process Orchestration allows multiple styles for Java namespace declarations, while Saxon (the processor in Cloud Integration) supports only one format. 

  1. a) Inline Declaration 

xmlns:java="http://xml.apache.org/xslt/java" 

<xsl:variable name="date" select="java:com.edi.xslthelper.DateTransform.GetDate(data)"/> 

  1. b) Namespace Declaration with Class Path 

xmlns:date="java:com.edi.xslthelper.DateTransform" 

<xsl:variable name="date" select="date:GetDate(data)"/> 

In Cloud Integration, only the second option (namespace declaration with class path) is supported. Therefore, all Java class calls must be manually adapted accordingly. 

 

  1. Type Handling in Java Class Calls 

Just like native XSLT functions, Java class calls in Cloud Integration require explicit type consistency. For example: 

<xsl:variable name="__function4" select="variable:setValue($var,'Name',string(number(data)))"/> 

If a Java class expects a string, the input must be explicitly converted. On SAP Process Orchestration, the same code might work without this conversion. 

In one specific migration case, a Java method required an integer input ‚Äî here, neither round() nor number() worked, but the XSLT function xs:integer() was necessary. 
 

Please note that compilation errors such as ‚ÄúErrors were reported during stylesheet compilation‚Äù are often related to incorrect data types. Explicitly converting inputs usually resolves these issues. 

 

References to other stylesheets within the XSLT 

XSLT code from different stylesheets can be used in an XSLT mapping using the include function: 

<xsl:include href="Stylesheet2.xsl"/> 

The included stylesheet needs to be added manually as a reference to the iflow: 

On Cloud Integration, no folder structures are supported so if the IA on PO had a nested folder structure containing the stylesheets, make sure to upload them individually and remove the path in the include function of your original stylesheet like our example above. 

 

Recommendations for Successful Migration 

To ensure smooth execution of XSLT mappings in Cloud Integration: 

  • Always verify and explicitly define correct data types. 
  • Adapt namespace declarations for all Java class calls. 
  • Adapt the include of additional stylesheets. 
  • Upload all necessary additional components (jar files, stylesheets). 
  • Test mappings individually after migration to detect type-related issues early. 
  • Simplify or refactor complex Java-dependent logic where possible. 

Following these guidelines helps prevent runtime errors and ensures stable, predictable execution after migration. 

 

Conclusion and Next Steps 

Migrating XSLT mappings from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite requires close attention to how the underlying XSLT processor interprets data types and Java extensions. 
While most mappings migrate seamlessly, subtle differences, particularly in data type handling, namespace declarations, and custom Java integrations, may lead to compilation or runtime issues if not adjusted. 

Stay tuned for the next part of this series, where we‚Äôll continue our deep dive into migration patterns and modernization best practices in SAP Integration Suite, including insights on content-based routing, custom code handling, and error management.

entry.title: FAQ ‚Äì Migration from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
This blog provides answers to the most frequently asked questions from customers and partners planning their migration from SAP Process Orchestration (PI/PO) to SAP Integration Suite.

This content was prepared by many experts from different areas at SAP and it covers assessment, tooling, technical migration topics, and operational aspects to help you plan and execute a smooth transition to SAP‚Äôs cloud-native integration platform.

Last Updated: Nov 2025 ‚Äì SAP Integration Suite Move Experts.

 

Assessment and Planning

This section is focused on questions related to the initial planning or assessment of your landscape, normally before the start of the migration project.

 

Q1: Why should I move from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite?

A: Migrating from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite enables organizations to modernize their integration landscape with a cloud-native, fully managed, and future-proof integration Platform as a Service (iPaaS) that supports both cloud and hybrid scenarios.

It eliminates infrastructure maintenance, reduces total cost of ownership, and accelerates time to value through more than 4000 prebuilt integrations, 4,600+ APIs, and approx. 1400+ business events available on SAP Business Accelerator Hub (as of end of 2025) and keep adding up. See more information in Value Proposition: Why You Should Move to SAP Integration Suite.

 

Q2: What is the Migration Assessment tool in SAP Integration Suite?

A: The Migration Assessment is a capability within SAP Integration Suite designed to analyze your SAP Process Orchestration interfaces providing many insights about the interfaces‚Äô complexity, dependencies, categories of functionalities and effort estimation for the technical migration. See more information in Migration Assessment.

 

Q3: Which SAP Process Integration/Orchestration versions are supported by the Migration Assessment?

A: The Migration Assessment supports SAP Process Integration/Orchestration versions:

  • 7.31 SP28 and above
  • 7.40 SP23 and above
  • 7.50 SP06 and above

The Migration Assessment supports interfaces created based on Interface Configuration Object (ICO) and interfaces created based on Receiver Determination (together with Sender Agreement, Receiver Agreement and Interface Determination) in dual stack environments.

Note: For 7.50 (SP06 to SP09), make sure to have implemented the patch as described in the SAP Note 2456339.

 

Q4: How can I start planning my migration project?

A: Begin by running the Migration Assessment to understand your system landscape and estimate migration efforts. Then define the migration strategy (e.g., phased migration, modernization on focus areas).

Review the Migration Guide, evaluate reusable content, and prepare your SAP Integration Suite tenants (development, test, and production). SAP recommends the Discovery Center mission Get Started with Migration to SAP Integration Suite to get confidence and understanding on the tools.

 

Q5: I have SAP Process Integration 7.1. Can I use the Migration Assessment and/or Migration Tool?

A: SAP cannot guarantee that the Migration Assessment and Migration Tool can work properly in an SAP Process Integration version different than the ones supported (see question 3), although many of the APIs used might be available on the same. SAP recommends upgrading the SAP Process Integration to a supported release before running the assessment and/or migration to ensure accurate results.

 

Q6: How can I determine the number of required message blocks while moving from SAP Process Orchestration to SAP Integration Suite?

A: In the Migration Assessment result, you can have the counting of message throughput and some performance indicators per interface such as the average message size, for the previous month that you ran the extraction. You can use both information to calculate the number of required messages blocks in SAP Integration Suite.

Make sure to activate the monthly performance collection on SAP Process Orchestration as per SAP Note 3300008.

For synchronous messages, you might need to check if synchronous messages are logged on the Message Overview Monitor as per the SAP Note 2442373. Make sure to read throughout the note and agree or not with any additional overhead due to the additional message logging in case this is not enabled, and you want to collect also such data.

For more information of what is the definition of a Message on SAP Integration Suite refer to the SAP Note 2942344 and Discovery Center.

 

Q7: Where can I find more information about how to use the Migration Assessment?
